The conversion of methane (CH4) and carbon dioxide (CO2) to more valuable chemicals is attracting attention from an industrial and environmental perspective; however, this process is a great challenge in catalysis, because of the high stabilities of CH4 and CO2. Herein, we investigate the CH4 and CO2 conversion to acetic acid over NU-1000 metal–organic framework (MOF)-supported single-atom catalysts (SACs) (M-NU-1000, M = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu) using density functional calculations. The reaction proceeds in three steps: first, a CH4 C–H bond dissociates to form a methyl intermediate. Then, an acetate intermediate is formed via C–C bond coupling between the methyl carbon atom and CO2. Finally, the acetate abstracts a proton to form the acetic acid product. We discover that Cu-NU-1000 exhibits the highest catalytic activity as compared to the other catalysts, based on its overall reaction barrier and rate constants. We also disclose two suitable descriptors to approximately predict the overall activation barrier of the reaction. One is the complexation energies difference between CO2 adsorbed on a methyl intermediate and CH4 adsorbed on the SACs used in this study. Another plausible descriptor is the difference between complexation energies of acetate intermediate and the CH4 adsorption. The supported NU-1000 MOFs are also found to accelerate the stability of all species formed along the reaction coordinates, especially during the transition states. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Methane conversion Carbon dioxide conversion Metal–organic framework Single-atom catalysts Density functional theory Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction The conversion of CH4 and CO2 (greenhouse gases linked to global warming) to other chemicals has attracted considerable interest from an industrial and environmental chemistry point of view. This process can not only provide alternative synthetic routes for value-added chemicals but also achieve a reduction of the net CH4 and CO2 emissions into the atmosphere [1–7]. Acetic acid is one of the chemicals that can ideally be formed via the direct conversion of CH4 and CO2; it is utilized as raw material for the production of many chemicals including acetic anhydride, vinyl acetate, and alkyl acetates [8–10]. This reaction has been proposed to conduct using various catalysts both homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts [11,12]. However, heterogeneous catalysis is considered more feasible in terms of easy separation and recycling from the reaction system. Several heterogeneous catalysts have been used in the conversion, especially metal-supported catalysts such as Cu/Co-based metal oxide [13], Pt/Al2O3 [14], Pd/SiO2 [15], Rh/SiO2 [15], Fe/ZnO [16], and metal-exchanged zeolites [17–21]. In recent years, a class of porous materials named metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have emerged as promising catalysts because of their structural flexibility, with a surface composition and pore structure that can be adjusted by altering the metal center or organic linker. These materials can also serve as useful solid supports for metals on well-defined catalytic sites. Previously, Zr-based MOFs have been reported to have the highest catalytic potential, with excellent thermal and chemical stabilities [22,23]. One of the most typical Zr-based MOFs is NU-1000, which consists of Zr6(μ3-O)4(μ3-OH)4(H2O)4(OH)4 clusters (Zr6 nodes) connected by 1,3,6,8-tetrakis(p-benzoate)pyrene (TBAPy4−) ligands to form a csq topology [24,25]. The Zr6 nodes consist of terminal hydroxo (–OH) and aquo (–OH2) ligands that can be anchored by various metals (i.e., Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, and Zn) to generate single-atom catalysts (SACs) via post-synthetic methods [26–29]. Previously studies revealed the potential activity of NU-1000-supported single-atom metals toward the activation of the C–H bonds of CH4 and some alkanes such as propane [30–33]. These catalysts also exhibit promising potential for CO2 activation and further conversion to the desired products [34,35]. These findings motivated us to study the activity of NU-1000-supported single-atom metals for the simultaneous conversion of CH4 and CO2 to the acetic product. In this work, density functional theory (DFT) calculations are carried out to gain deeper insights into the conversion of CH4 and CO2 to acetic acid over NU-1000 MOFs supporting a series of single-atom catalysts (Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu). We analyze both mechanistic and energetic features to reveal the different catalytic activity of the supported single-atom metal catalysts and predict the optimal metal for the studied reaction. These results provide new insights to help design effective catalysts for the acetic acid formation from CH4 and CO2. 2 Computational models and details 2.1 NU-1000 cluster models Fig. 1 a shows the NU-1000 structure which contains Zr6(μ3-O)4(μ3-OH)4(H2O)4(OH)4 nodes connected to eight TBAPy4− organic linkers per node to form porous network. The cluster model of NU-1000 employed in this work contained one Zr6 node in which eight TBAPy4 − organic linkers were replaced by formate groups to reduce the computational costs and maintain the overall charge balance (Fig. 1b). This simple model has been previously employed to mimic the active site of the NU-1000 MOF [36]. Two protons of the original terminal -OH2 and -OH groups on Zr6 nodes were exchanged by metals (M = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu) in +2 oxidation state to model the metal support on the Zr6 node and generate the single-atom active site, forming M-NU-1000 (Fig. 1b). 2.2 Electronic structure calculations All structure optimizations were performed using DFT calculations at the M06-L [37] level, as implemented in the Gaussian 16 code [38]. This is the method of choice for transition metals as well as inorganic and organometallic metal systems [39]. The M06-L functional has been reported to deliver high-quality results in previous studies of hydrocarbon adsorption and reaction mechanisms in zeolites and metal–organic frameworks [40–54]. The polarized double-ζ 6-31G(d,p) basis set was employed for the C, O, and H atoms, while the transition metal atoms (Zr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu) were described by the Stuttgart–Dresden (SDD) effective core potential [55]. The reaction was assumed to proceed entirely in the high-spin state of the system. During geometry optimization, the interacting molecules and the entire cluster model except the para C atoms of the formate group were allowed to relax. Vibrational frequency calculations at the same level of theory were performed on the optimized geometries to identify the nature of all stationary points along the reaction coordinate and to obtain Gibbs free energies. Transition states were confirmed to present only one imaginary frequency, corresponding to the expected motion of atoms toward the subsequent intermediate or product. Atomic charges and orbital energies were calculated with the natural bond orbital (NBO) method [56]. The relative energies in this work are reported as Gibbs free energies (ΔG) at the temperature of 298.15 K and 1 atm. The temperature correction of electronic energy is given as in Eq. (1) (1) G = E 0 + E tot + k B T − T S tot where G is the Gibbs free energy of a calculated structure, E0 is the total electronic energy of the structure, Etot is the internal thermal energy, kB is Boltzmann's constant, T is the calculated temperature and Stot is internal thermal entropy. The adsorption free energy change is defined according to Eq. (2). (2) Δ G = G comp lex − G probe − G MOFs where G complex is the total Gibbs free energy of a particular adsorbed adsorbate on M-NU-1000 MOFs, G probe is the Gibbs free energy of an isolated adsorbate, and G MOFs is the Gibbs free energy of an isolated M-NU-1000 catalyst. Moreover, we calculated the forward rate for the CH4 C–H bond dissociation using classical transition state theory (TST), according to the following equation: (3) k = k B T h exp ( − Δ G # overall RT ) where k is the rate constant, kB is Boltzmann's constant, h is Planck's constant, T is the temperature, R is the universal gas constant, and ΔG # overall is the overall free energy barrier. The rate constants were derived from reaction temperatures of 298.15 K and 523.15 K. The latter temperature is relevant to an experimental analysis of direct catalytic conversion of CH4 and CO2 to acetic acid catalyzed by microporous-based catalysts [17,18]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structures, energies, and reaction mechanism We first investigate the reaction mechanism along with the structural and energetic changes of the CH4 and CO2 conversion to acetic acid over M-NU-1000. The reaction takes place in three steps: (i) CH4 C–H bond dissociation, (ii) C–C bond coupling between the methyl carbon atom and CO2, and (iii) acetic acid formation, as shown in Fig. 2 . The proposed mechanism is analogous to the previously reported of the CH4 and CO2 conversion to acetic acid on metal‑exchanged MFI zeolites [57,59]. The relative free energy profile is shown in Fig. 3 . The optimized structures for the reaction on M-NU-1000 are displayed in Figs S1-S5 of the Supplementary data. Initially, the CH4 molecule is adsorbed on the metal site of M-NU-1000 (Ads). In all systems, the total charge of the CH4 molecule was more positive, while the positive charge on the metal site was reduced respected to isolated systems, indicating electron transfer from CH4 to the MOF active site. The C–H bond of CH4 dissociates via the TS1 transition state; in this process, the H1 proton of CH4 transfers to the O1 active oxygen of the catalyst and simultaneously the C1 of CH4 moves toward the metal site, leading to shorter O1⋅⋅⋅H1 and C1⋅⋅⋅M distances (see Fig. 2). The activation barriers of the CH4 C–H bond dissociation, relative to the energy of the isolated molecule, increase as follows: Fe-NU-1000 (27.3 kcal/mol) < Cu-NU-1000 (28.4 kcal/mol) < Co-NU-1000 (31.0 kcal/mol) < Mn-NU-1000 (33.0 kcal/mol) ≤ Ni-NU-1000 (33.8 kcal/mol), as shown in Fig. 3. These activation energies are in the range of those obtained for C–H activation on metal‑exchanged MFI zeolites, as reported previously [57–59]. However, these barriers are slightly higher than the C–H activation energies in CH4 adsorbed on Cu-functionalized Zr6O8 MOF nodes (25.2 kcal/mol) [30], Fe doped ZnO (6.9 kcal/mol) [16], and In2O3-supported (ZnO)3 (17.5 kcal/mol) [60]. The reason for their lower activation barrier is because the active oxygen atom (O1) on the surface of mentioned catalysts are more active than OH groups of M-NU-1000 family, leading to the more catalytic activity in C–H activation Previous studies found that the electron-donation interaction between the C−H σ bond of CH4 and the unoccupied orbitals of the metal is essential for breaking the C−H bond [57,59,61]. We analyzed the charge difference between the C−H σ bonds in the CH4 adsorption and transition state complexes (q TS1 – q Ads) of all systems, using the NBO method to describe this C–H bond dissociation. We found that the total charge of the C−H σ bond becomes more negative, indicating an electron transfer from the metal site to the C−H bond. The charge difference tends to be higher in the case of Fe-NU-1000 than those of other M-NU-1000 catalysts, leading to its smallest activation energy (Ea). A correlation plot shown in Fig. 4 a demonstrates the relationship between charge difference and activation energy. The transition state then forms the methyl intermediate and a water molecule (Int1) adsorbed on the metal and the Zr site, respectively. The energies of this intermediate complex (relative to reactants) range from 9.4 (Cu-NU-1000) to 21.5 kcal/mol (Ni-NU-1000). We also analyzed the Brønsted−Evans−Polanyi (BEP) relationships to estimate free energy barriers for the C–H bond dissociation based on the calculation of reaction energy [62,63]. The correlation between the free energy of C–H bond dissociation (ΔG# C-H = GTS1 – GAds) and the reaction free energies of the C–H bond dissociation step (ΔGreaction,C-H = GInt1 – GAds), is displayed in Fig. 4b. The free energy barriers can be estimated from a linear regression with an R2 determination coefficient of 0.570. The reaction then proceeds via the C–C bond coupling step, which starts from the co-adsorption of a CO2 molecule on the metal active center of the methyl intermediate (Int1_CO2). The calculated relative energies relate to isolate reactants range from 13.2 to 27.7 kcal/mol (see Fig. 3). The structure of the adsorbed CO2 does not changes much, due to its weak adsorption interactions. The lengths of the C–O bonds of CO2 do not differ from those of the isolated molecule. Then, the reaction proceeds via the TS2 transition state, in which CO2 is inserted into the M−C1 bond through nucleophilic attack. TS2 is considered a four-center transition state, formed through the breaking of the M−C1 bond and the formation of the M−O and C1−C2 bonds [64]. This is in contrast with the SE2 mechanism observed in Pd-CH3 [65] and Ni-CH3 [66] complexes as well as Zn-doped ceria surfaces [61], in which the CO2 molecule attacks the methyl group from the open side of the M-CH3 bond. In the transition state, the C1–C2 bond distance decreases while the M–C1 bond length increases compared to Int1_CO2. The linear structure of the CO2 molecule is distorted with respect to that of the isolated molecule, with the O–C–O angle ranging from 141.5° to 150.7°, depending on the metal. Furthermore, both C–O bond lengths in CO2 increase compared to those of the co-adsorption state. The structural trends of these transition states are comparable with those observed in previous theoretical studies of CO2 insertion in metal–CH3 species on metal-exchanged zeolites [57–59]. The activation barriers relative to the co-adsorption complex are 17.1, 19.2, 20.9, 19.1, and 22.8 kcal/mol for Mn-, Fe-, Co-, Ni-, and Cu-NU-1000, respectively (see Fig. 3). These energies are in the range of those previously reported for the same reaction on metal-exchanged zeolites (∼7 – 22 kcal/mol) [57], Fe doped ZnO (17.3 kcal/mol) [16] and Zn-doped ceria surfaces (11.8 kcal/mol) [61]. However, these barriers are still lower than those of the C–C coupling on other single oxide catalysts. For example, the energy on CeO2 (65.3 kcal/mol) [67] is significantly higher than those obtained from the reaction on In2O3-supported (ZnO)3 (33.4 kcal/mol) and on In2O3-supported Ga2O3 (47.0 kcal/mol) [60]. The acetate intermediate Int2 is formed after the C–C bond coupling step, with the insertion of CO2 into the M−C1 bond. This intermediate is adsorbed on the surface as a bidentate structure with two oxygen atoms bound to the metal center. As shown in Fig. 3, the complexation energies of the acetate intermediate in all systems are exothermic (−0.4 to −6.4 kcal/mol). Furthermore, we considered the energy barriers for both the C–C bond coupling to the acetate intermediate and the reverse reaction to form the Int1-CO2 state. The forward reaction toward the acetate intermediate is both kinetically and thermodynamically favored; as a result, the C–C bond coupling step is spontaneous for all MOFs. Subsequently, the acetate intermediate can be converted to the acetic product, as shown in the Int2 to Prod pathway in Fig. 2. Acetic acid is formed via a transition state corresponding to the protonated acetate intermediate (TS3), in which the H1 proton shifts from the O1 to the O2 atom, resulting in an increased O1–H1 bond distance and decreased O2–H1 distance in the transition state. This step involves low activation barriers, ranging from 0.8 kcal/mol for Mn-NU-1000 to 6.7 kcal/mol for Cu-NU-1000. These results imply that the acetate can be easily converted to the acetic product, similar to the catalytic activity of metal-exchanged zeolites [59]. However, they are in contrast with the reaction on Zn-doped ceria, which involves high activation energies (61.8 kcal/mol) due to the highly stable acetate intermediate [61]. The acetic acid product (Prod) is adsorbed on the metal active site via its carboxylate group. The complexation energies relative to the isolated reactant molecules are in range of 2.9 to –5.8 kcal/mol. Finally, to regenerate the active site of catalysts, the acetic acid product is desorbed by requiring the energy of 28.9, 26.4, 29.4, 24.3, and 20.7 kcal/mol for Mn-, Fe-, Co-, Ni-, and Cu-NU-1000, respectively. The reaction energy value is 17.0 kcal/mol. As expected, these energies are agree well with the experimental data [10]. Additionally, we calculated the relative free energies for the reaction on M-NU-1000 at 523.15 K to compare with the ones calculated from 298.15 K. The similar trend has been found as can be seen in the results listed in Tables S1-S2 of the Supporting Information. 3.2 Comparison of catalytic activities of NU-1000-supported metal catalysts As shown in Fig. 3, the rate determining transition state is the one of C–C bond coupling (TS2) while the rate determining intermediate is the CH4 adsorption (Ads). The overall free reaction barriers (ΔG# overall) are consequently considered from the energy differences between TS2 and Ads and is defined as follows: (4) Δ G # over all = G TS 2 − G Ads where GTS2 and GAds are free energies of the TS2 and Ads, respectively. The ΔG# overall are calculated to be 42.0, 37.3, 42.0, 45.9, and 32.5 kcal/mol, for Mn-NU-1000, Fe-NU-1000, Co-NU-1000, Ni-NU-1000, and Cu-NU-1000, respectively. Rate constants of the reaction are also calculated from the obtained overall activation energies using classical TST, as listed in Table 1 . The rate constants (k) obtained from 298.15 and 523.15 K are in the order of Cu-NU-1000 > Fe-NU-1000 > Co-NU-1000 ∼ Mn-NU-1000 > Ni-NU-1000. Hence, the combination of overall activation energies and rate constants suggest that Cu-NU-1000 is kinetically favored than the other studied MOF catalysts. Furthermore, it is found that the desorption step of acetic acid on the Cu-NU-1000 active site is more favorable than on the other catalysts due to the least desorption energy (20.7 kcal/mol). We therefore predict that the Cu-NU-1000 could be a potential catalyst for the studied reaction. We also analyze statistical relationships between MOF properties and the height of the overall reaction barrier, for the purpose of applying these properties as descriptors to predict the catalytic activity of MOFs. We initially determine a correlation between ΔG# overall and the energy of the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) with the alpha-electron spin of the M-NU-1000 MOFs. A linear regression gives R 2 of 0.662 (see Fig. 5 a). However, this LUMO is expected as a low-accuracy descriptor for estimating ΔG# overall due to its moderately low R2. We also discover the relationship between the ΔG# overall and other parameters, especially the relative energies of intermediate species along the reaction coordinates, to propose descriptors. We obtain a good linear fitting between overall activation energy and the complexation free energy of Int1_CO2 (ΔGInt1_CO2), as shown in Fig. 5b. The corresponding relationship (R 2 = 0.720) is as follows: (5) Δ G # o v e r a l l = 0.883 ( Δ G I n t 1 _ C O 2 ) + 22.74 As shown in Fig. 5b, the ΔG# overall estimated from this linear relationship (LR) are in fairly agreement with those obtained by the calculations, with a mean absolute error (MAE) of 2.0 kcal/mol. We further study the relationship between ΔG# overall and free energy differences between Int1_CO2 and CH4_Ads (ΔGInt1_CO2 − ΔGAds), and between Int2 and CH4_Ads (ΔGInt2 − ΔGAds). An excellent linear fitting is found for both cases, as shown in Fig. 6 . Therefore, both complexation free energies difference are predicted to be good descriptors for an approximation of the overall activation barrier. The corresponding relationships are as follows: (6) Δ G # o v e r a l l = 0.743 ( Δ G I n t 1 _ C O 2 − Δ G A d s ) + 24.99 (7) Δ G # o v e r a l l = 1.821 ( Δ G I n t 2 − Δ G A d s ) + 48.57 According to Eqs. (5) and (6), the overall activation barriers can be extrapolated by using only two energy points on the NU-1000 catalysts, without determining the location of the transition state. The MAE for the calculation of ΔG# overall by ΔGInt1_CO2 − ΔGAds and ΔGInt2 − ΔGAds is 1.0 and 0.6 kcal/mol, respectively. Note that we also consider some possible by-products that can be produced during the reaction of the acetic acid synthesis from CH4 and CO2 [16,68]. The Cu-NU-1000 is selected for this calculation due to its higher catalytic activity compared to the others, as discussed above. For the calculations, we calculate the CO2 hydrogenation to formate (HCOO) intermediate which can be further converted to the formic acid (HCOOH) by-product. The activation energy is calculated to be 69.7 kcal/mol (see Fig. S6), which is approximately four times higher than the C–C coupling of CH3 with the adsorbed CO2 (22.8 kcal/mol). Additionally, the dissociation of methyl group (CH3) to a methylene group (-CH2) on the active site of Cu-NU-1000 is examined, as shown in Fig. S7. This step requires a barrier of 37.9 kcal/mol, which is higher than the energy in C–C coupling step. From the energy profiles of calculated systems, these side reactions would not be facile over single-atom supported NU-1000 MOFs used in this work, resulting in an increase of selectivity in the desired product, acetic acid. 3.3 Effect of supported NU-1000 framework We also perform calculations for the conversion of CH4 and CO2 to acetic acid on a catalyst model without the NU-1000 node to demonstrate the effects of the support material. Cu-NU-1000 was chosen for these calculations again, owing to its lowest overall activation barrier for the reaction. The model contains only Cu coordinated with two hydroxide groups to retain the Cu charge (Fig. S8). To avoid the effect of structural differences, we perform single point calculations on the optimized structures. The obtained relative energies of the systems formed along the reaction coordinate are shown in Fig. 7 . All species of adsorbed intermediates and transition states are stabilized by the supported NU-1000 framework. The CH4 C–H bond dissociation step requires an activation energy of 55.9 kcal/mol, which is higher than the one with the NU-1000 cluster (28.4 kcal/mol). It might be due to the supported NU-1000 framework act as a reservoir of electron density that can assist charge transfer from the metal active site to the C−H bond, leading to the easier C-H bond breaking. Activation energies for the C–C bond coupling and for acetic acid formation step without the Zr-NU-1000 framework are 25.9 and 14.8 kcal/mol, respectively. These energies are higher than the ones with the NU-1000 support. Moreover, the overall reaction barrier that is calculated from the energy difference between CH4_Ads and TS2 is also found to be almost two times higher than the one with the supported MOF (60.1 vs 32.5 kcal/mol). Therefore, it can be suggested that the supported NU-1000 framework stabilizes the species that formed along the reaction coordinates and increases the activity of the Cu active site for the conversion of CH4 and CO2 to acetic acid. 4 Conclusions We use density functional theory calculations to investigate the conversion of CH4 and CO2 to acetic acid over different metal atoms (Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu) supported on NU-1000 metal–organic frameworks. The proposed reaction mechanism consists of (i) CH4 C–H bond dissociation, (ii) C–C bond coupling between the methyl carbon atom and CO2, and (iii) acetic acid formation. We found that the rate determining intermediate is the CH4 adsorption and the rate determining transition state is the transition state for the C–C bond coupling. The overall activation free energies are calculated to be 42.0, 37.3, 42.0, 45.9, and 32.5 kcal/mol; for Mn-NU-1000, Fe-NU-1000, Co-NU-1000, Ni-NU-1000, and Cu-NU-1000, respectively. Based on the calculated overall barriers and reaction rates, the catalytic activities of the M-NU-1000 materials are in the order of Cu-NU-1000 > Fe-NU-1000 > Co-NU-1000 ∼ Mn-NU-1000 > Ni-NU-1000. We observe a strong linear relationship between overall activation energies versus the energy differences between complexation energy of CO2 on a methyl intermediate and the energy of the CH4 adsorption complex (ΔGInt1_CO2 − ΔGAds). A similar relationship is also found when plotting the activation free energies with the complexation free energy differences between an acetate intermediate and CH4 adsorption (ΔGInt2 − ΔGAds). Both energy differences are therefore proposed as suitable descriptors for predicting the overall potential energy surface of the reaction. We finally show that the supported NU-1000 framework is acted as an electron reservoir which plays important role in assisting electron transfer and stabilizing all species along the reaction coordinate, especially in the transition states. coredata.dc:description: The conversion of methane (CH4) and carbon dioxide (CO2) to more valuable chemicals is attracting attention from an industrial and environmental perspective; however, this process is a great challenge in catalysis, because of the high stabilities of CH4 and CO2. Herein, we investigate the CH4 and CO2 conversion to acetic acid over NU-1000 metal–organic framework (MOF)-supported single-atom catalysts (SACs) (M-NU-1000, M = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu) using density functional calculations. The reaction proceeds in three steps: first, a CH4 C–H bond dissociates to form a methyl intermediate. Then, an acetate intermediate is formed via C–C bond coupling between the methyl carbon atom and CO2. Finally, the acetate abstracts a proton to form the acetic acid product. We discover that Cu-NU-1000 exhibits the highest catalytic activity as compared to the other catalysts, based on its overall reaction barrier and rate constants. We also disclose two suitable descriptors to approximately predict the overall activation barrier of the reaction. One is the complexation energies difference between CO2 adsorbed on a methyl intermediate and CH4 adsorbed on the SACs used in this study. Another plausible descriptor is the difference between complexation energies of acetate intermediate and the CH4 adsorption. The supported NU-1000 MOFs are also found to accelerate the stability of all species formed along the reaction coordinates, especially during the transition states.
coredata.dc:title: Computational study of the conversion of methane and carbon dioxide to acetic acid over NU-1000 metal–organic framework-supported single-atom metal catalysts
